awd_titl_txt: STANDARD GRANT: Indexing Energy Performance in Housing Servicescapes: A Multiscale Study in the U.S. Mid-Atlantic Region
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores energy vulnerability as a social and technical problem. Energy vulnerability occurs when a household cannot afford to maintain temperature levels suitable for health and wellbeing. Existing research shows that factors such as the amount of available housing, energy markets, and government policies all contribute to energy vulnerability, and that energy vulnerability disproportionally affects the elderly, the disabled, renters, and low-income families. The investigator on this project will use a combination of ethnographic observations, in-depth interviews, and focus group research to understand the extent of energy vulnerability in three US counties, how energy providers work to address it, and how energy vulnerability relates to energy performance mechanisms. This research will provide important information for developing new policies and insights that could help to reduce energy vulnerability in the future.

The project uses a multi-site ethnographic approach incorporating participant observation, in-depth interviews, and focus groups to explore: (1) energy vulnerability across three different US counties; (2) the sociotechnical strategies used by energy services organizations to address energy vulnerability; and (3) how energy performance mechanisms shape energy efficiency at different spatial and temporal scales. Research will be conducted through the Energy Coordinating Agency (ECA), a multi-state nonprofit organization that works with state and federal programs to address energy vulnerability, and at four ECA energy centers. Qualitative analyses of media reports and internal reports and documents from the Energy Coordinating Agency will be used to supplement other forms of data gathering. The main goals are to advance understanding of the dynamics of energy vulnerability in the US, to share these insights to find ways to help reduce energy vulnerability, and to show how energy performance can be used as an analytic framework for theorizing how humans interact with technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF research succeeded in many of its original objectives, even though the project was carried out during the global COVID-19 pandemic.

 

The project successfully collaborated with our subcontractor, the Energy Coordinating Agency (ECA), whose staff members worked closely with research team members on key aspects of the study design -- in monthly and ad hoc meetings that taught the research team about the intricacies of energy assistance and by introducing researchers to critical stakeholders at Philadelphia?s Neighborhood Energy Centers. More than 350 structured and open-ended interviews were conducted with household energy users as well as with local energy experts. The research team also worked with ECA and community partners to host fifteen energy education workshops (June-September 2021) and two conferences (October 2020 and October 2021).

 

The research team produced a number of critical findings over the course of the project. The most important of these findings related to under-utilization of energy assistance programs. Extreme gaps exist between federal program application requirements and the lived realities of many energy vulnerable households, including true costs of living and energy use; the myriad rhythms and timeframes that may be out of sync, which prevent households from meeting federal program requirements; and the difficulties of navigating information about utility assistance without the help of social service staff.

 

Another key finding is that Pennsylvania?s deregulated energy market has put many energy vulnerable households in harm?s way due to predatory sales practices among alternative energy suppliers. This has had the effect of creating distrust for the energy sector, including traditional institutions like utilities as well as emerging renewable energy businesses.

 

It is also the case that medically vulnerable households, not only have greater energy needs, which often makes energy use more expensive, but that there are very few programs and policies to support medically vulnerable households access affordable utility services. This makes such households doubly vulnerable.

 

The research team succeeded in designing, installing, and building a digital archive using open source software. The archive documents all project activities, including all collected data (interview transcripts, survey responses, and fieldnotes taken while conducting participant observations); meeting notes; annotated news articles, research papers, and gray materials; and publications produced by the research team (nearly two dozen media briefs, four research newsletters, a brochure, six conference papers, and one peer-reviewed article). As additional publications become available, they will be publicly archived in this platform. The platform will be maintained and updated in its current form until 2032.

 

In terms of mentorship and methods training, the project funded eight undergraduate and graduate research assistants, who worked on the project for lengths ranging from ten weeks to over three years. Additionally, the PI designed and taught two courses at Drexel based on the project design. The first course, ?The Energy Vulnerability Lab? was a graduate-level field school taught to twelve Drexel students between March and June 2020. The second course was an undergraduate seminar titled ?Energy and Society? which attracted students from Political Science, Environmental Science, Mechanical Engineering, and Information Security degree programs. The syllabus and lesson plans for both courses are published in the project?s public archive with extension documentation.
